titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Laura Stedman Papers
titlestmt.author: by Christopher Geissler, Tom Hyry, and Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Sunday December 9, 2018 at 05:26

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, writings, and personal papers which document the personal and professional life of Laura Stedman. The correspondence highlights personal and professional affiliations with Edmund Clarence Stedman (grandfather), Dr. George M. Gould (husband), and a number of writers including Martha Dickinson Bianchi, Ednah Proctor Clarke (Hayes), and Cora Miranda Baggerly Older. The papers include examples of Stedman's writing, publications, and a run of her scrapbook journals.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Laura Stedman Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Laura Stedman Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection includes materials previously identified by the call number Za Dies, having been mistakenly identified as the papers of Laura Woodworth Stedman Gould Dies. This identification reflected an erroneous spelling of the last name of Laura Stedman's second husband, the donor of the papers, Milton Seabury Dees. The collection also includes material previously separated and cataloged under Za Brower which has been reintegrated.
Most of the descriptive information used in the inventory of this finding aid was derived from folder notes and catalog cards created by previous staff members of the Beinecke library.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Laura Woodworth Stedman was born in 1881, the daughter of Frederick Stuart Stedman and Ellen Montague Douglas Stedman, and the granddaughter of banker, editor, and poet, Edmund Clarence Stedman. She was educated at private schools in New York City, including Arundell Academy and the Brackett School. Stedman served as literary secretary to her grandfather in the decade preceding his death in 1908 and, thereafter, as his literary executor. In 1908 Stedman contributed a bibliography to George M. Gould's Concerning Lafcadio Hearn . Working with Gould again, she edited a two-volume edition of her grandfather's letters, Life and Letters of Edmund Clarence Stedman (1910). In 1916 she published a short appreciation of Bayard Taylor in The Mid-West Quarterly . The following year Stedman and Gould married, taking up residence in Atlantic City, New Jersey. After Gould's death in 1922, Stedman remained in Atlantic City through 1930, in which census she is listed as a widow and an author. At the time of her death in 1939, Stedman was married to Milton Seabury Dees and resided in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, writings, and personal papers that document the personal and professional life of Laura Stedman. The correspondence constitutes the larger part of the collection and highlights personal and professional affiliations with Edmund Clarence Stedman (grandfather), Dr. George M. Gould (husband), Ellen Douglas Stedman (mother), and a number of writers including Martha Dickinson Bianchi and Cora Miranda Baggerly Older. Of particular note is the correspondence group related to her work as literary agent for the writer Ednah Proctor Clarke (Hayes), which includes correspondence, playscripts, and contractual agreements between a range of interested parties including the actress Khyva St. Albans and a number of theatrical producers. Writings include notes and a typescript for a play titled "The Conquering Flame," notes and correspondence related to the editing and publication of the letters and manuscripts of Edmund Clarence Stedman, and limited collected writings of other authors, including Mary S. Edgar. The personal papers include materials related to Stedman's education, including an early report card and school notebooks; a run of scrapbook journals containing notes, photographs, postcards, and clippings which document a range of interests; and collected visual materials including drawings attributed to Albert Bierstadt and Petrella da Bologna.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence, 1887-1930; II. Writings, circa 1902-1928. III. Personal papers, 1888-1931.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Edmund Clarence Stedman Collection, YCAL MSS 1008.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence is organized into three subseries: General, Personal, and Professional.
General and personal correspondence are arranged alphabetically by name; professional correspondence is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of incoming and outgoing correspondence of Laura Stedman. The General and Personal correspondence include similar material, but the Personal correspondence is comprised of more extensive exchanges with family and friends that were previously separated out by Stedman and library staff. Professional correspondence includes correspondence related to her work as a writer, editor, and literary agent as well as voluntary efforts related to World War I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: General correspondence is comprised of incoming correspondence.

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence addressed to Laura Stedman and Ellen Douglas Stedman (mother).

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence addressed to Edmund Clarence Stedman and Laura Stedman

scopecontent.p: Personal correspondence includes both incoming and outgoing correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes clippings and programs related to performances of Ayenara Alexeyeva and Holger Alexeyev-Mehner, single intaglio print by Jean de Paleologue (signed PAL).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Incoming correspondence addressed to Edmund Clarence Stedman, Ellen Douglas Stedman, and Laura Stedman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Incoming and outgoing correspondence between Laura Stedman and George M. Gould and members of the Brower family. The bulk of the material is comprised of correspondence between Laura Stedman (Gould) and Pauline Florence Brower.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, includes clippings and photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous third-party correspondence and notes related to Pauline Florence Brower and family.

did.unittitle: Older, Cora Miranda Baggerly (Mrs. Fremont Older)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material includes third-party correspondence addressed to Edmund Clarence Stedman.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Outgoing correspondence, documenting travel, includes postcards.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Outgoing correspondence comprised of 1 autograph letter signed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 4 autograph letters signed to Mrs. E. C. Stedman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes drawings ("wiggles") and discussion of a Billy Sunday campaign (1918).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous correspondence with relatives and friends arranged by Laura Stedman according to year: 1925-1930. Though the bulk of the material falls within the given time period, the chronological arrangement is not strict and files frequently contain groupings from individual correspondents that vary from the ascribed date.

Correspondents include: Helen R. Albee (Mrs. John Albee), Rebecca Baker, Marjory Bonar, Eleanor P. Clarke, Alpheus Geer, Mrs. S. A. B. Harvey, Jesse G. Hollingsworth, Elizabeth Dodge Huntington, John G. Kello, Evelyn Nichols Kerr, Marguerite Langdon Larned (Mrs. William Trowbridge Larned), Helen Marsh (Mrs. Edward C. Marsh), Harry Marshall (florist), Ada Sterling, Mathilde L. Thomas, Kathryn Davison Tulloch (Mrs. Rudolph Lang Tulloch), Rudolph Lang Tulloch, Josephine Griswold Wardlaw, Grace M. Warner, Herbert P. Whitlock.

did.unittitle: Library of American Literature , Edmund Clarence Stedman, ed.
Literary representation of Ednah Proctor Clarke (Hayes)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence concerning efforts to produce Ednah Proctor Clarke's play "The Chrysalis" (alternately identified as "The Judgment Seat"). Material includes playscript drafts, notes, contractual agreements, and third-party correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Writings are arranged alphabetically by subject.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Notes and typescript for a play

arrangement.p: Series III is arranged alphabetically by subject

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 27 note-books, containing copies in her handwriting of various poems, together with postcards, photographs, and newspaper clippings.
